description: From Middle French réductif, from Late Latin reductivus, from the participle stem of Latin reducere (“to reduce”).

adjectives.description: reductive (comparative more reductive, superlative most reductive)

entries.meaning: (Scotland law, now rare) Pertaining to the reduction of a decree etc.; rescissory. [from 16th c.]
Causing the physical reduction or diminution of something. [from 17th c.]
(chemistry, metallurgy, biology, economics) That reduces a substance etc. to a more simple or basic form. [from 17th c.]
examples: On the relative reductive powers of different classes of American coals, as demonstrated by the experiments with oxide of lead.

entries.meaning: (now rare, historical) That can be derived from, or referred back to, something else. [from 17th c.]
examples: But then beside the primary and direct sense of the text, the ancients commonly supposed that there was a reductive or anagogical meaning, in which it might be taken.

entries.meaning: (now frequently derogatory) That reduces an argument, issue etc. to its most basic terms; simplistic, reductionist. [from 20th c.]
